dataset.title: Koonibba Survey, Biological Survey of South Australia - Vegetation Survey, Biological Database of South Australia

creator.id: Department of Environment, Water and Natural Resources
creator.organizationName: Department of Environment, Water and Natural Resources

dataset.abstract: A survey conducted to record species and plant associations throughout the remnant vegetation at Koonibba. The Koonibba Survey is part of the Biological Survey of South Australia Program which is a series of systematic surveys conducted across the state between 1971 and the present with the broad aim of providing a baseline inventory of South Australia's flora and fauna biodiversity. Please use the following URL to access the dataset: http://aekos.org.au/collection/sa.gov.au/bdbsa_veg/survey_127

contact.organizationName: Department of Environment, Water and Natural Resources, South Australia

methodStep.description: Study Location Establishment Method: Study location establishment involves recording the location coordinate of the site, either with GPS or from aerial photos aligned to digital topographic mapsheets. If the site is permanently marked a site photograph is taken from this marker. If the site is not permanently marked the photgraph is generally taken in the centre of the plot to be representative of the plot vegetation and landscape features. The geographic distribution of Biological Survey Vegetation sites can be viewed ; Study Location Visit Method: Once the Study Location Selection Method has been completed a field team, usually comprising a botanist and a physical observer, visit the site to conduct the vegetation survey. Due to the remote nature of many of these sites a large amount of preparation is required to ensure that all field equipment is available to surveyors when in the field. Repeat visits (and associated observation methods) may occur following fire, flood or other significant environmental events, but are not very common. ; Soil Surface Cover Method: onduct an assessment of the sampling plot for the proportion of the plot that is covered by bare earth and plant detritus (leaf litter). Other elements of cover, such as standing vegetation and cryptogam (liverwort, moss and lichen) cover are not recorded in this assessment. ; Vegetation Assessment Method: The vegetation assessment method records all vascular plant species diversity, abundance/cover, life stage, structure and condition within the sampling plot. Species sampling is not time bounded, that is, species search within the plot is continued until no new species are found. Species field identifications are confirmed by the systematic collection of voucher specimens of each species encountered on the survey trip. Voucher specimens are lodged with the State Herbarium of SA and determinations are performed by herbarium staff. Various classifications and measures are used to describe the canopy element of the vegetation assemblage on the plot. ; Vertebrate Evidence Method: The plot is examined for evidence of past or present vertebrate species occurrence. Evidence can be either direct observation of vertebrate species within the plot or inferential evidence of species occurrence. Categories of vertebrate evidence include: dung; tracks; burrows/warrens/nests; sighting of vertebrate; trace material (e.g. skeleton, feather, skin). Detection of trace evidence such as skeletons, feathers or fur may trigger the collection of a voucher specimen which can be used to confirm or refine the species identity and/or for genetic analysis. ; Structural Formation Method: Conduct an assessment of the Structural Formation of the overstorey vegetation within the plot. Structural Formation is defined as: the dominant growth form, cover and height of the ecologically dominant stratum (from the Australian Native Vegetation Information System web page (http://www.environment.gov.au/erin/nvis/). This method focuses on the dominant and co-dominant overstorey species as identified in the Species Assessment Method. Life form is based on Muir's (1977) definitions. ; Canopy Age Class Method: The representation of different age classes of the dominant and co-dominant tree species in the overstorey isassessed to provide an indication of condition, population dynamics and recruitment at the plot. The presence of hollows in trees is recorded as an indicator of habitat value for animal species that use hollows for nesting or shelter. ; Structural Summary Method: To assess the structural assemblage of all vascular plant species present on the plot. Where structural assemblage is defined as the dominant strata layers that are visible when viewing the vegetation in cross section. ; Vegetation Species Assessment Method: Assessment of all vascular plant species occurring within the plot for every visit to the site. Species identification is substantiated by the collection of voucher specimens of each vascular plant species which are then identified by Herbarium curators once the specimens have been dried and mounted. Species are assessed for the additional attributes of dominance within the plot, cover/abundance category, life stage and life form. Search within the plot is continued until no new vascular plant species are found. ; Canopy Assessment Method: Where vegetation is dominated by shrubs, trees or mallees the cover/density of the canopy vegetation is assessed by categorising the cover into standard classes. ; Overstorey Measurement Method: A line transect is selected to measure the volume and separation of 10 individuals of any species belonging to the canopy stratum. The transect should start within the plot, but can extend beyond the plot if required to make up the 10 measurements. Measurements are used to calculate crown separation ratios and average canopy volumes for each plot visit. ; Vegetation Species Life Stage Assessment Method: Assessment of the life stage of all vascular plant species occurring within the plot for every visit to the site. Life stage is based on a set of standard categories with potentially more than one applying to a single species. A classification of life stage is recorded for every vascular plant species within the plot. Greater than 10% of individuals of that species in the plot must exhibit the life stage for it to be recorded. ; Voucher Collection Method: All vascular plant species observed on the plot within a survey visit period are represented by voucher specimens. Voucher specimens should be selected to contain as many diagnostic features as possible to allow accurate identification including: flowers; stems; leaves/phyllodes; bark and rhizomes as appropriate. Plant specimens also allow update of species records if species taxonomy is revised. ; Voucher Determination Method: Voucher specimen determination (based on latin determinavit) is a process by which field species identification is verified, corrected or resolved to a finer scale.
